documents.document: RT @LMegaparsec: @NatalieLanovill 💙💙💙💙💚💙
RT @MsEisha: @NatalieLanovill *hugs* My condolences and prayers.
RT @eastvanhalen: @NatalieLanovill Sending love. Holler if you need anything. xx
RT @SteveinKW: @NatalieLanovill Sorry for your loss, Natalie.
@SteveinKW Thank you. The response to my post was so overwhelming I missed your comment. All the best.

ST: And now it's done. Her number will follow her into the ether. Her phone, now an artifact, has nothing more to say to me, and will be revived in someone else's hands. That advance scout of love, fun, and anticipation, has run out of road. 7/7

ST: Once her hospital stays started, it was important evidence that things were OK. It meant that she was well enough to talk, to answer her own phone, to CHARGE her phone. It meant she hadn't been too sick to bring it with her. 6/

ST: The first call or text from her when she arrived in town meant we were about to do something fun together. Laugh. Eat. Hug. Catch up in a way that is difficult over the phone. Do something new.
Mum LOVED to do something new. 5/

ST: It was also the platform of visitation. I can literally feel on every level the experience of communicating with her on her way to visit me. Receiving texts from her when she got back home safely. Texting her updates from the road myself. 4/
ST: Mum's cell phone was first and foremost a symbol of her independence. Mum LOVED to be out and about, so if I needed to call her cell it meant she was doing something in the world. 3/
ST: Mum and I had lived in different cities for 23 years, so we had in many ways learned to live without each other. So certain minor things have taken on extra meaning. 2/

Sub-thread: I cancelled mum's cell phone today. It was surprisingly sad and painful. Melissa, the @RogersHelps CSR, was amazing. The call took almost 90 minutes. #Grief #Loss #Bereavement #Farewell 1/?
